instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the convolutional neural network (CNN) model for in vivo nerve recognition, and how far can this metric go in the related study in the research on in vivo nerve recognition?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the convolutional neural network (CNN) model for in vivo nerve recognition was sensitivity and specificity. Sensitivity measures the proportion of true positive results, which indicates how well the CNN model can correctly identify nerves. Specificity measures the proportion of true negative results, indicating how well the model can correctly identify non-nerve tissue types. 

The sensitivity achieved by the CNN model for nerve recognition was an average of 0.76, meaning it correctly identified nerves in 76% of cases. The specificity achieved was 0.99, indicating that the model correctly identified non-nerve tissue types in 99% of cases. 

These metrics demonstrate that the CNN model has a high level of accuracy in recognizing nerves in in vivo hyperspectral images. However, it is important to note that there is still room for improvement, as the sensitivity could be higher.

instruction: How were the machine learning models used in the research on in vivo nerve recognition using hyperspectral imaging and deep learning?
Output: The machine learning models were used to train and recognize different tissue types, including nerves, in the hyperspectral images obtained during the research. Specifically, a convolutional neural network (CNN) was utilized as the best model for this purpose. The CNN was trained using the hyperspectral imaging (HSI) data from an animal model, where eight anesthetized pigs underwent neck midline incisions to expose various structures such as nerves, arteries, veins, muscles, fat, and skin. The CNN was trained to recognize and differentiate these tissue types based on their spectral properties in the HSI data. The performance of the CNN model was evaluated using metrics such as sensitivity and specificity, achieving an average sensitivity of 0.76 and a specificity of 0.99 for nerve recognition.
